Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: ABI Development: A Modular, Community Based Design Platform for Synthetic Biology (Clotho)
Award.AbstractNarration:
Synthetic biology attempts to design novel biological systems to address a number of challenges in bioenergy, biotherapeutics, and bioremediation. However, synthetic biology is facing two very fundamental challenges: data management and standardization. This project will complete the development of the Clotho software platform for synthetic biology. Clotho is an environment which links repositories of biological data (databases) to modular, user created 'Apps' through a common interface which reflects a data model specifically tailed to synthetic biology. Apps then can be used together to create specific design flows ranging from high level specification of biological functionality all the way down to basic sample tracking and laboratory management. The project strives to (1) create the first standardized data model for synthetic biology captured as a software platform. (2) To create a complete application programming interface to access this data model via software 'Apps'. (3) To create a global community of users via a website designed from the ground up to create, share, and collaborate around software development. (4) To create a polished initial software distribution including appropriate user interfaces and applications to address the immediate needs of synthetic biology labs.

The broader significance of this project is to establish a design framework for the automation and standardization of software in synthetic biology. Educational opportunities include Clotho development in the International Genetically Engineered Machine (iGEM) competition. Design automation coursework will use Clotho at UC Berkeley and Boston University. The App store (clothoapps.org) will serve as a portal not only for Clotho development but also as a community resource. Discussions regarding software tool development and use, documentation of ongoing research projects, and storage and retrieval of code and software libraries will be enabled by this effort. Finally, the International Workshop on Bio-Design Automation (IWBDA) will host Clotho developer and user meetings.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Synthetic biology attempts to design novel biological systems to address a number of challenges in bioenergy, biotherapeutics, and bioremediation.  Synthetic biology has the potential to be a highly interdisciplinary field with applicability to any number of scientific and engineering challenges. However, synthetic biology is facing two very fundamental challenges: data management and standardization.

Software tools for synthetic biology historically are an ad-hoc collection of boutique solutions designed to address specific challenges. What is needed is a true software platform that will address the data management challenge by integrating information stored in databases into a common framework upon which independent tools can be written. These tools can then begin to address the interoperability and standardization challenges by using a common data model and data exchange standards.

This project completed much of the development of the Clotho 3.0 software platform for synthetic biology. Clotho is an environment which links repositories of biological data (databases) to modular, user created “Apps” through a common interface which reflects a data model specifically tailed to synthetic biology. Apps then can be used together to create specific design flows ranging from high level specification of biological functionality all the way down to basic sample tracking and laboratory management.

The major intellectual merit goals of the project relate to completing the development of the Clotho software design environment for synthetic biology. We completed a conversion from version 2.0 of the software to 3.0. which:


(1) completed the core Clotho 3.0 software architecture allowing for a web-based "client/server" architecture. This allows for anyone to use Clotho directly from their browser and for software and feature updates to be made from one central location.

(2) efficiently deployed the 3.0 software while creating a user community. This is embodied by "SynBioTrails" at http://synbiotrails.org. This site uses Clotho as an educational tool to introduce users to both synthetic biology and the Clotho platform.

(3) completed a minimal initial Clotho 3.0 App distribution.These Apps include tools to describe biological systems with code (Eugene), create biological genetic circuits (Cello), and social media platforms for synthetic biology (Phagebook).

Clotho 3.0 can now be found at www.clothocad.org

The broader impact outcome of this project was the creation of the Nona Research Foundation (www.nonasoftware.org) which serves not only to house Clotho and its associated Apps, but also to be a repository for open source software for the entire synthetic biology community.
